Brief Hospital Course:
___ y/o ___ homeless F with PMHx of TBI, HIV+, HCV, 
polysubstance abuse (alcohol, crack cocaine, and heroin), 
unspecified mood disorder (MDD with psychotic features vs. 
substance-induced mood disorder), and chronic AH who presented 
from ___ station via EMS with complaint of multiple head strikes 
found to have EtOH intoxication and SI admitted to MICU for EtOH 
withdrawal and CIWA monitoring, now stabilized and transferred 
to the floor, now medically stable for discharge to psychiatric 
facility

ACTIVE ISSUES:
========================
# EtOH intoxication/withdrawal: on phenobarbital withdrawal 
protocol.
NOTE 0 Last drink ___.

NOTE 0 Patient was loaded with 
phenobarbital, which may continue if the accepting psychiatric 
facility is okay with administering, however there is no 
contraindication to discontinuing.

NOTE 0 -Phenobarb protocol while inpatient, stopped at discharge
-Continued MVI, thiamine, folate
-Hydroxyzine PRN for additional agitation
-seen by psychiatry and social work - appreciated.

NOTE 0 # Suicidal ideation: patient repeatedly stating "I have suicidal 
thoughts" and "I'm depressed," though is unable to fully 
elaborate.

NOTE 0 Psychiatry saw the patient and had the following 
recommendations: -Patient meets ___ criteria for 
involuntary admission, may not leave AMA, should continue 1:1 
observation.

NOTE 0 -Would hold on any psychiatric medications given acute alcohol 
withdrawal.

NOTE 0 -If chemical restraint necessary, please call psychiatry for 
specific recs.

NOTE 0 Please be aware that patient has cited "jaw 
locking" with Haldol administration in the past, thus would 
consider alternative antipsychotic.

NOTE 0 - seen by psychiatry - recommended inpatient psychiatric 
placement, and transferred to deac 4.
NOTE 0 # FEVER: Patient febrile to 101 in the ED.

NOTE 0 No localizing signs 
of symptoms of infection.

NOTE 0 Suspect that this was likely related 
to acute ingestion, however given her murmur which has not been 
documented previously,  obtained TTE which showed no evidence of 
vegetation or endocarditis.

NOTE 0 # Psychosis: suspect this is part of underlying psych disorder 
and not necessarily alcoholic hallucinosis.

NOTE 0 Will defer to 
psychiatry.

NOTE 0 -Appreciate Psychiatry recs

========================

medications, will defer to outpatient.

NOTE 0 # HCV: not on active treatment
- Monitor LFTs, as above

NOTE 0 Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to ___ for evaluation of numerous falls, 
alcohol and substance abuse.

NOTE 0 While you were here you were 
briefly in the intensive care unit where you were started on 
phenobarbital to help you withdrawal from alcohol and prevent 
delirium tremens.

NOTE 0 You also disclosed that you were not taking 
any of your HIV medications.

NOTE 0 You were started on Bactrim as 
prophylaxis for opportunistic infections, and should follow up 
with your outpatient providers regarding restarting your HIV 
medications and for evaluation of your hepatitis C.  You were 
deemed medically stable for discharge to a psychiatric facility.

Discharge Instructions:
Medications
You will be given a prescription for pain medicine.

NOTE 2 The pain 
medication is a codeine derivative and should be taken as 
directed.

NOTE 2 Please take one full strength aspirin (325 mg) each day for six 
weeks to decrease the risk of having a complication related to a 
blood clot.

NOTE 2 Please take a stool softener, like Colace (Docusate Sodium 
100mg), twice a day while taking narcotics to prevent 
constipation.

NOTE 2 Dressing
Leave your dressing for 48 hours after your surgery.

NOTE 2 After 48 
hours, you may remove your dressing.

NOTE 2 LEAVE THE TAPE STRIPS OVER 
YOUR INCISIONS.

NOTE 2 These will stay on for 1.5 to 2 weeks and will 
slowly peel off.

NOTE 2 Showering
You may shower 48 hours after your surgery and get your 
incisions wet.

NOTE 2 DO NOT immerse in a tub or pool for 7  10 days 
to avoid excessive scarring and risk of infection.

NOTE 2 When you shower, let your arm hang at your side (Do NOT raise 
your arm).

NOTE 2 To wash under your arm, lean forward carefully and let your arm 
hang.
NOTE 2 Using your other hand, wash under your operative arm.

NOTE 2 Do 
NOT scrub the incision.

NOTE 2 When you are done, stand up and let 
your arm hang at your side.

NOTE 2 Pat yourself dry and put your sling 
on.

NOTE 2 Ice Packs
Keep Ice Packs on at all times exchanging every hour while 
awake.

NOTE 2 Icing is very important to decrease swelling and pain 
and improve mobility.

NOTE 2 After 24 hours, continue to use the cuff 
3  4 times a day, 15  20 minutes each time to keep swelling to 
a minimum.

NOTE 2 Activity
 Take it easy.
NOTE 2  Wear your sling for comfort and safety.

NOTE 2  Keep your arm at your side at ALL TIMES  no reaching, 
grabbing or pulling with your operative arm.

NOTE 2 When to Contact Us
If you experience severe pain that your pain medication does not 
help, please let us know.

NOTE 2 If you have a temperature over 101.5º, please contact our office 
at ___.

NOTE 2 Physical Therapy:
Activity:   Activity:  Activity as tolerated Activity:  OOB to 
chair for meals
 Right lower extremity:  Non weight bearing
Encourage turn, cough and deep breathe q2h when awake

overwrap any dressing bleedthrough with ABDs and ACE

PSYCHIATRIC:
#Acute mania: schizoaffective disorder vs. bipolar I disorder
Ms. ___ presentation of elevated mood, reduced sleep with
increased energy, distractability, and mildly pressured speech 
was considered
consistent with acute mania.

NOTE 3 Her symptoms of disorganized 
thought
process and behavior were consistent with acute psychosis, 
likely
related to her current manic episode.

NOTE 3 On admission, she refused 
to take risperidone or zyprexa.

NOTE 3 She said that she would take 
latuda.
NOTE 3 However, she then refused latuda.

NOTE 3 She ultimately agreed 
to take zyprexa, and she was started on zyprexa 5mg PO BID.

NOTE 3 This 
dose was then increased to zyprexa 5mg PO QAM and 10mg PO QHS.

NOTE 3 She was also treated with ativan 1mg PO BID, which was then 
reduced to 1mg PO daily and then stopped.

NOTE 3 On this medication 
regimen, she gradually improved.

NOTE 3 She began sleeping and her 
psychotic symptoms of paranoid delusions and disorganized 
thought process resolved.

NOTE 3 At the time of discharge, she was 
sleeping well and had become less disorganized.

NOTE 3 She reported a 
"good" mood and felt like she was back to her baseline.

NOTE 3 She 
denied suicidal or homicidal ideation.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the plastic surgery service on 
___ and had an immediate reconstruction of nipple-sparing 
mastectomy with deep inferior epigastric perforator flap from 
the contralateral side, harvest of pedicle of the flap, and 
anastomosis of the thoracodorsal artery and vein.

NOTE 4 She tolerated 
the procedure well.

NOTE 4 Neuro: The patient received morphine PCA with good effect and 
adequate pain control.

NOTE 4 When tolerating oral intake, the patient 
was transitioned to oral pain medications.

NOTE 4 CV: The patient was stable from a cardiovascular standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.

NOTE 4 Pulmonary: The patient was stable from a pulmonary standpoint; 
vital signs were routinely monitored.

NOTE 4 GI/GU: Post-operatively, the patient was given IV fluids until 
tolerating oral intake.

NOTE 4 Her diet was advanced when appropriate, 
which was tolerated well.

NOTE 4 She was also started on a bowel 
regimen to encourage bowel movement.
NOTE 4 Foley was removed on POD#2.
NOTE 4 Intake and output were closely monitored.
NOTE 4 ID: Post-operatively, the patient was started on IV cefazolin.

NOTE 4 The patient's temperature was closely watched for signs of 
infection.

NOTE 4 Prophylaxis: The patient received subcutaneous heparin during 
this stay, and was encouraged to get up and ambulate as early as 
possible.

NOTE 4 At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile 
with stable vital signs, tolerating a regular diet, ambulating, 
voiding without assistance, and pain was well controlled.

NOTE 4 Medications on Admission:
Depakote, fluoxetine, quetiapine, trazodone

Discharge Instructions:
Return to the ER if: 
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
medications.

NOTE 4 * If you have shaking chills, fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
degrees or 38 (C) degrees, increased redness, swelling or 
discharge from incision, chest pain, shortness of breath, or 
anything else that is troubling you.

NOTE 4 * Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
concern you.

NOTE 4 * Please resume all regular home medications and take any new 
meds as ordered.

NOTE 4 * Do not drive or operate heavy machinery while taking any 
narcotic pain medication.

NOTE 4 You may have constipation when taking 
narcotic pain medications (oxycodone, percocet, vicodin, 
hydrocodone, dilaudid, etc.

NOTE 4 ); you should continue drinking 
fluids, you may take stool softeners, and should eat foods that 
are high in fiber.
NOTE 4 * ___ nursing services will help you with JP drain care.

NOTE 4 Empty 
JP drains daily and record daily output.
